title: U.S. News:  CDC Backs  Pfizer,  Moderna  Vaccines  Over J&J's  ----  By Peter Loftus
text:
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended adults take a Covid-19 vaccine from Pfizer Inc. or Moderna Inc. over Johnson & Johnson's after agency officials reported the rate of a rare but serious blood-clotting condition was higher than previously detected.

The CDC made the move Thursday, following a 15-0 vote by advisers encouraging use of vaccines other than J&J's.

The agency noted similar recommendations have been made in other countries, including Canada and the U.K. People unable or unwilling to receive a Pfizer or Moderna vaccine, the CDC said, will continue to have access to the J&J vaccine.

The updated position is likely to deal another blow to the use of the J&J shot, whose uptake had been hurt by manufacturing issues and earlier reports of J&J vaccine recipients, especially women, experiencing blood clots combined with low blood-platelet levels.

There have been at least 54 cases of the condition, thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome, or TTS, among J&J vaccine recipients in the U.S., including nine resulting in deaths, CDC officials said Thursday.

The rate of cases is higher than previously estimated in men and women, and in a wider age range, the officials said.

"I just cannot recommend vaccines associated with a condition that may lead to death," said Pablo Sanchez, a pediatric infectious-disease specialist at the Ohio State University-Nationwide Children's Hospital in Columbus, Ohio., who serves on the panel of CDC advisers.

J&J said it remained confident in the overall positive benefit-risk profile of its vaccine. "The safety and well-being of those who use the Johnson & Johnson vaccine continues to be our No. 1 priority," said Mathai Mammen, global head of J&J's pharmaceutical research and development.

He said the company will work with the CDC on next steps and strongly supports education about rare events such as TTS and how to manage it.

J&J's Covid-19 vaccine is based on a different technology than the messenger RNA used in the Pfizer and Moderna shots.

J&J's vaccine includes a harmless version of a virus that can cause the common cold, which is engineered to contain genetic instructions that set off an immune response. The mRNA vaccines don't contain any viral material and use a different way of delivering a genetic code that sets off an immune response.

As of Aug. 31, CDC officials said at the advisers' meeting, about 3.8 cases of TTS were reported for every million doses of J&J vaccine administered, across all recipients. The rate was highest among women ages 30 to 39, at 10.6 per million doses.

CDC officials also said that among those who develop TTS, the fatality rate was about 15%. The people who died deteriorated quickly after being admitted to the hospital. CDC officials said getting J&J's vaccine was still superior to not getting vaccinated, but the balance between the benefits and risks for the messenger RNA vaccines from Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna was superior to J&J's. And the current supply of mRNA vaccines in the U.S. is adequate, unlike earlier in the year.

Health officials say people with an allergy to ingredients in the mRNA vaccines, or who have had a severe allergic reaction to a dose of those vaccines, shouldn't receive them.
